chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, everyone, let's get started.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So today's lecture and Wednesday's lecture,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we're going to talk about this thing called

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: object-oriented programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if you haven't programmed before,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I think this is a fairly tough concept to grasp.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But hopefully with many examples and just

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: by looking at the code from the lectures,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you'll hopefully get the hang of it quickly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's talk a little bit about objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we've seen objects in Python so far.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Objects are basically data in Python.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So every object that we've seen has a certain type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That we know.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Behind the scenes, though, every object

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: has these two additional things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: One is some data representation, so how

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Python represents the object in just behind the scenes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And what are different ways that you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can interact with the object?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for example, every one of these is a different object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For example, this is the number 1,234.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's a specific object that is of type integer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The number 5 is a different object that's of type integer,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We've seen floats.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We've seen strings.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We've seen lists.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Lists and dictionaries are more complicated objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Object types, sorry.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But every object has a type, some sort of way

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that it's represented in Python, and some ways

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that we can interact with them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the idea behind object-oriented programming

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is, first of all, everything in Python is an object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We've said that before.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in this lecture, I think, we'll

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: really get at what that means.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we've seen strings, integers, dictionaries, lists.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Those are all objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: When we did functions, we saw that we

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: could pass as a parameter another function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So functions were also objects in Python.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So literally everything in Python is an object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what are the kinds of things we can do with objects?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, once you have a type, you can create a new object that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is of some type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you can create as many objects

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as you'd like of that particular type, an integer 5,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: an integer 7.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Those all work in a program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Once you've created these new objects,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can manipulate them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for a list, for example, you can append an item

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to the end of the list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can delete an item, remove it,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: concatenate two lists together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's ways that you can interact with objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the last thing you can do is you can destroy them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So with lists, we saw explicitly that you can delete elements

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from a list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or you can just forget about them

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: by reassigning a variable to another value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then at some point, Python will

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: collect all of these dead objects

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and reclaim the memory.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's continue exploring what objects are.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's say I have these two separate objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: One is a blue car.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: One is a pink car.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So objects are really data abstractions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So these two cars can be created by the same blueprint.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is a blueprint for a car.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if an object is a data abstraction,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: there's two things that this abstraction

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is going to capture.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The first is some sort of representation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What is going to represent the car?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What data represents a car object?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the second is, what are ways that we

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can interact with the object?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if we think about a car blueprint,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: some general representation for a car

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: could be the number of wheels it has, the number of doors

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it has, maybe its length, maybe its height.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is all part of what data represents the car.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The interface for the car is what are ways

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you can interact with it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for example, you could paint a car.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you could change its color.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You could have the car make a noise.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And different cars might make different noises.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or you can drive the car.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So these are all ways that you can interact with a car.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Whereas the representation are what makes up the car,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what data abstractions make up the car.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's bring it a little closer to home by looking at a list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we have this data type of list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We've worked with lists before.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The list with elements 1, 2, 3, and 4

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is a very specific object that is of type list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Again, we think about it in terms of two things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: One is what is the data representation of a list?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So behind the scenes, how does Python see lists?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the second is how do you interact with lists?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what are ways that you can manipulate a list object

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: once it's created?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So behind the scenes, you have a list L,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which is going to be made up of essentially two things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: One is going to be the value at specific index.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So at index 0, it has the value 1,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because it's the first element in the list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the second thing that represents a list

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is going to be this second part, which is a pointer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And internally, this pointer is going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to tell Python where is the memory location in the computer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: where you can access the element index 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's just essentially going to be a chain going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from one index to the other.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And at the next memory location, you have the value at index 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you have another pointer that takes you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to the location memory where the index 2 is located.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And at index 2, you have the value,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and then the next pointer, and so on and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is how Python internally represents a list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: How you manipulate lists, we've done this a lot.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can index into a list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can add two lists together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can get the length.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can append to the end of a list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can sort a list, reverse a list,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and so many other things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So these are all ways that you can interact with the list

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: object as soon as you've created it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So notice both of these, the internal representation

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and how you manipulate lists, you don't actually

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: know internally how these are represented.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: How did whoever wrote the list class

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: decide to implement a sort?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We don't know.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You also weren't aware of how these lists were represented

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: internally.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you didn't need to know that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's the beauty of object-oriented programming

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and having these data abstractions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The representations are private of these objects,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and they're only known by what you can find out how it's done.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But they only should be known by whoever implemented them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You, as someone who uses this class,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: doesn't really need to know how a list is represented internally

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in order to be able to use it and to write

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: cool programs with them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So just final motivation here before we

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: start writing our own types of objects

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is the advantages of object-oriented programming

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is really that you're able to bundle this data,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: bundle some internal representation and some ways

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to interact with a program into these packages.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And with these packages, you can create objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And all of these objects are going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to behave the exact same way.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They're going to have the same internal representation

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and the same way that you can interact with them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And ultimately, this is going to contribute

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to the decomposition and abstraction ideas

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that we talked about when we talked about functions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that means that you're going to be

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: able to write code that's a lot more reusable

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and a lot easier to read in the future.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So just like when we talked about functions,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we're going to sort of separate the code that we talk about

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: today into code where you implement a data type

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and code where you use an object that you create.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So remember when we talked about functions,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you were thinking about it in terms of writing a function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you had to worry about the details of how

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you implement a function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you had to worry about just how to use a function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's sort of the same idea today.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when you're thinking about implementing your own data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: type, you do that with this thing called a class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And when you create a class, you're

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: basically going to figure out what name you want to give your class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you're going to define some attributes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And attributes are going to be the data representation and ways

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you can interact with your object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you as the programmer of this class

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are going to decide how you want people

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to interact with the object and what data this object is going to have.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for example, someone wrote code that implements a list class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we don't actually know how that was done.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But we can find out.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So creating the class is implementing the class

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and figuring out data representation and ways

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to interact with the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Once that's done, you can then use your class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you use the class by creating new instances of the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when you create a new instance,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you essentially create a new object that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: has the type, the name of your class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you can create as many objects as you'd like.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can do all the operations that you've defined on the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for example, someone wrote the code to implement a list class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you can just use the list class like this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can create a new list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can get the length of the list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can append to the end of the list, and so on and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's start defining our own types.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So now you're going to write classes which are going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to define your own types of objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for today's lecture, we're going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to look at code that's going to be in the context of a coordinate

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And a coordinate object is essentially

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to be an object that's going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to define a point in an xy plane.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So x comma y is going to be a coordinate in a 2D plane.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we're going to write code that's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to allow us to define that kind of object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the way we do that is we have to define a class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we have to tell Python, hey, I'm defining my own object

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you do that with this class keyword.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you say class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Then you say the name of your type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In this case, we're creating a type called coordinate.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Just like we had type list, type string, and so on,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: this is going to be a type called coordinate.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then in parentheses here, you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: put what the parents of the class are.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For today's lecture, we're going to define a class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For today's lecture, the parent of the classes

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are going to be this thing called object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And object is the very basic type in Python.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It is the most basic type in Python.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it implements things like being able to assign variables.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So really, really basic operations

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you can do with objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So your coordinate is therefore going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to be an object in Python.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we've told Python we wanted to find an object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So inside the class definition, we're going to put attributes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what are attributes?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Attributes are going to be data and procedures

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that belong to the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Data are going to be the data representations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And procedures are going to be ways that we

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can interact with the object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The fact that they belong to the class

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: means that the data and the procedures that we write

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are only going to work with an object of this type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you try to use any of the data or the procedures

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with an object of a different type,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you're going to get an error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because these objects, this data, and these attributes,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: sorry, will belong to this particular class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the data attributes is what is the object?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What is the data that makes up the object?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for our coordinate example, it's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to be the x and y values for our coordinate.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We can decide they can be ints.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We can decide that we can let them be floats.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But it's going to have one value for the x-coordinate

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and one value for the y-coordinate.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So those are data attributes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And procedure attributes are better known as methods.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you can think of a method as a function,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: except that it's a function that only works

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with this particular type of object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: so with a coordinate object in this case.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the methods are going to define how

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can interact with the object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in a list, for example, we've said

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you can append an item to the end of the list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We can sort a list, things like that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when you're defining methods, you're

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: defining ways that people can interact with your object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for example, for a coordinate object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we can say that we can take the distance between two

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: coordinate points.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's going to be a way that you can

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: interact with two coordinate points.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And just to be clear, these are going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to belong to this class, which means that if you try to use

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: this distance method on two lists, for example,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you're going to get an error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because this distance method was only

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: defined to work with two coordinate type objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's carry on and continue implementing our class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we've written this first line so far, class coordinate

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So now let's define attributes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: First thing we're going to define are data attributes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Generally, you define data attributes inside this init.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this is underscore, underscore,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: init, underscore, underscore.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's a special method or function in a class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the special method tells Python,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: when you implement the special method,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it tells Python when you first create an object of this type,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: call this method or call this function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So how do we do that?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's implement it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you say def, because it's just a function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The name is the special name init.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we give it some parameters, just like any other function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: These last two parameters are x and y,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which are going to represent the x.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's going to represent how you create a coordinate object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you give it a value for the x coordinate,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and you give it a value for the y coordinate.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The self, however, is a little bit trickier.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the self is going to be a parameter

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: when you define this class that represents

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a particular instance of the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we're defining this coordinate object

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in sort of a general way.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We don't have a specific instance yet,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because we haven't created an object yet.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But this self is going to be sort of a placeholder

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for any sort of instance when you create the object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in the definition of the class,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: whenever you want to refer to attributes that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: belong to an instance, you have to use self dot, so this dot

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: notation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the dot is going to say, look for a value x.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Sorry, look for a data attribute x that belongs to this class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
